name: sweet sorghum production | sweet sorghum grain | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/2585/documentation

This dataset represents the cultivation of sweet sorghum on an area of 1 ha producing the co-products sweet sorghum grain and sweet sorghum stem. The yield of sweet sorghum grain is 3860 kg/ha at a moisture content at storage of 9.1%, the yield of sweet sorghum stem is 48263 kg/ha at a moisture content of 73%.;;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

This activity starts after the harvest of the previous crop. The inputs of seeds, mineral fertilisers and pesticides are considered. It is assumed that no organic fertilisers are applied. Seed input is approximated by reducing the yield by 5 kg (required amount of seed per hectare for sowing)


The dataset includes all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, combine-harvest and transport from field to farm (15 km). Further, direct field emissions are included. This activity ends after harvest at the farm gate.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0111:Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for China.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Transports are modelled with standard distances. Data for the usage of pesticides are taken from US production. Machine usage is modelled with Chinese processings and Swiss diesel consumptions. Emissions are calculated with standard methods.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=CN
Average yield per hectare (2001-2005; FAOSTAT Database Query: Sorghum Production. Retrieved 16. May 2006, from http://faostat.fao.org/faostat/). The original value is 3865 kg/ha; 5 kg of grain are needed as seed input (Smith & Frederikson 2000). As there is no separate dataset for sorghum seed, the 5 kg seed are directly subtracted from the yield.

flow.name: sweet sorghum grain
flow.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0111:Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds

exchanges.description:
The exchange has been updated from 'ammonium nitrate, as N' into 'ammonium nitrate' and therefore its amount has been scaled (multiplied) from 40 kg by 2.8573 kg of 'ammonium nitrate' per kg of 'ammonium nitrate, as N'.
EcoSpold01Location=RER

defaultProvider.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2012:Manufacture of fertilizers and nitrogen compounds

exchanges.description: Calculated as the difference between heavy metal input through fertilisers and output through the harvested product. Heavy metal contents of sorghum grains (Cu and Zn) according to Smith & Frederikson (2000). Heavy metal contents of sorghum stems according to Smith & Fredeiksen (2000) (Zn) and BIOBIB (1996) (Cd, Cu, Pb). Heavy metal contents of mineral fertilisers according to  Nemecek et al. (2004). Negative values represent a net export of heavy metals. --- Sources: Nemecek T., Heil A., Huguenin O., Meier S., Erzinger S., Blaser S., Dux D. & Zimmerman A. (2004) Life Cycle Inventories of Agricultural Production Systems. Ecoinvent report no. 15. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Duebendorf, Switzerland. --- BIOBIB (1996): Reisinger K., Haslinger C., Herger M., Hofbauer H. (1996) BIOBIB - a Database for Biofuels. THERMIE- Conference: Renewable Energy Databases, Harwell (United Kingdom).

flow.name: Copper ion
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to soil/agricultural

exchanges.description: Total amount of active substance/s of pesticides needed for the production of sweet sorghum stem is calculated to be circa 1.89E+00 kg. Pesticide/s used in this dataset is/are: '[sulfonyl]urea-compound', 'acetamide-anillide-compound, unspecified', 'atrazine', 'benzoic-compound', 'glyphosate', 'metolachlor', 'organophosphorus-compound, unspecified', 'phenoxy-compound'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of pesticide/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 3.79E+00 kg of packaging for pesticides is justified with this exchange.

exchanges.description: Total amount of active substance/s of fertilisers needed for the production of 'sweet sorghum stem' is calculated to be circa 4.80E+02 kg. Fertiliser/s used in this dataset is/are: 'ammonium nitrate, as N', 'lime', 'phosphate fertiliser, as P2O5', 'potassium chloride, as K2O', 'urea, as N'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of fertiliser/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 9.60E+02 kg of packaging for fertilisers is justified with this exchange.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
The application of pesticides is approximated by data on sweet sorghum production in the USA. The amounts of active ingredients stem from NASS (2004). Substnaces that are not availabe in the ecoinvent database are approximated by inventories of superordinate chemical classes. The inventories were assigned according to Sutter (2010, Tab. 2.25). If no inventory for the active ingredient or the corresponding chemical class was available, the pesticide was approximated with the product “pesticide, unspecified”. --- Sources: Sutter J. (2010) Life Cycle Inventories of Pesticides. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, St. Gallen, Switzerland.

flow.name: Transformation, to annual crop, irrigated, intensive
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/land

exchanges.description: Calculated as the difference between heavy metal input through fertilisers and output through the harvested product. Heavy metal contents of sorghum grains (Cu and Zn) according to Smith & Frederikson (2000). Heavy metal contents of sorghum stems according to Smith & Fredeiksen (2000) (Zn) and BIOBIB (1996) (Cd, Cu, Pb). Heavy metal contents of mineral fertilisers according to  Nemecek et al. (2004). Negative values represent a net export of heavy metals. --- Sources: Nemecek T., Heil A., Huguenin O., Meier S., Erzinger S., Blaser S., Dux D. & Zimmerman A. (2004) Life Cycle Inventories of Agricultural Production Systems. Ecoinvent report no. 15. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Duebendorf, Switzerland. --- BIOBIB (1996): Reisinger K., Haslinger C., Herger M., Hofbauer H. (1996) BIOBIB - a Database for Biofuels. THERMIE- Conference: Renewable Energy Databases, Harwell (United Kingdom).

The exchange has been updated from 'urea, as N' into 'urea' and therefore its amount has been scaled (multiplied) from 40 kg by 2.1438 kg of 'urea' per kg of 'urea, as N'.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
The application of pesticides is approximated by data on sweet sorghum production in the USA. The amounts of active ingredients stem from NASS (2004). Substnaces that are not availabe in the ecoinvent database are approximated by inventories of superordinate chemical classes. The inventories were assigned according to Sutter (2010, Tab. 2.25). If no inventory for the active ingredient or the corresponding chemical class was available, the pesticide was approximated with the product “pesticide, unspecified”. --- Sources: Sutter J. (2010) Life Cycle Inventories of Pesticides. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, St. Gallen, Switzerland.
